channel.title: Web dev technologies?
channel.description:
I'm about to start a web development project with some fellow students of mine. We haven't really seen much about technologies besides html, css and javascript yet. This project will include interaction with a database.
I'm fairly new to web development so need some info on what technologies to learn / use. I know there probably isn't a [i]better[/i] programming language, but which one do you prefer and why? PHP, RoR, Django, .. ?
Thanks in advance!

item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:

[quote=“Lothy, post:43, topic:547919”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=666824.msg4463044#msg4463044 date=1418585173]
Im not a huge fan of Play personally.
[/quote]

Seriously though, I haven’t used Play either. But it seems like the best choice if you’re going to do any JVM-based web development.[/quote]

thats why im writing a framework cause the options are limited

item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“Snow_, post:3, topic:547919”]Hmm I don’t know… if I’ve learnt anything from passively browsing these forums it’s don’t trust ashi[/quote]HAHAHA! My man!

[quote=“Lothy, post:20, topic:547919”]Have heard good things about Python, haven’t used it myself.
Ruby is for hipters. Steer clear.[/quote]
“Have heard good things about Python, haven’t used it myself.” - It’s great! But don’t take my word for it (which you probably won’t anyways), try it yourself! Coming from other OOP languages, it’s extremely easy to learn, and it’s functionality is quite good.

“Ruby is for hipters. Steer clear.” - Hipsters* first of all. And 2nd! He’s lying. Ruby is quite good if you research on it and use it a bit. I’m not extremely knowledgeable when it comes to Ruby - but the few times I’ve used it, I’ve enjoyed it quite a bit.

Read full topic

item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:32, topic:547919”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=666824.msg4459638#msg4459638 date=1416881656]

People need to understand how bloated Rails really is and realise that it’s fudgeing stupid to keep using it for stupid trivial things. Sinatra, if you want to stick with Ruby, is a great choice

Would be a totally valid point if Rails wasn’t modular and you couldn’t choose what parts of it to use, and Sinatra wasn’t missing so many features that most applications need that by the time you make it viable you’ve made it even more bloated than Rails was to start with.
[/quote]Why use Rails, a bloated framework with a bunch of modules hacked together into an unreusable hierarchy, instead of small, simple modules that do one thing and one thing well? Sinatra literally isn’t supposed to be an all in one package. You should find the modules to do exactly what you need to do as they’re less “jack of all trades”. Think Unix.[/quote]Probably because you can refactor a larger project in rails into smaller service modules. RoR really isn’t that bloated, but that’s what happens when you formulate your opinion based on what other people have said.

Read full topic

item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:37, topic:547919”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=666824.msg4462438#msg4462438 date=1418236736]

You should find the modules to do exactly what you need to do as they’re less “jack of all trades”. Think Unix.

That’s… what Rails allows you to do. That’s exactly why it’s now seperate modules. To use your Unix analogy, active_record is berkeley db, Rails is Solaris.
[/quote]If you can use the separate modules separately (in different programs that aren’t Rails) then I’d say it’s fine. If that’s the case then disregard what I said regarding Rails and apply it to any other unmodular monolithic framework.[/quote]No. Don’t tell me what to do.

Read full topic

If that’s the case then disregard what I said regarding Rails and apply it to any other unmodular monolithic framework.

item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:33, topic:547919”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=666824.msg4462345#msg4462345 date=1418178758]

People need to understand how bloated Rails really is and realise that it’s fudgeing stupid to keep using it for stupid trivial things. Sinatra, if you want to stick with Ruby, is a great choice

Would be a totally valid point if Rails wasn’t modular and you couldn’t choose what parts of it to use, and Sinatra wasn’t missing so many features that most applications need that by the time you make it viable you’ve made it even more bloated than Rails was to start with.
[/quote]Why use Rails, a bloated framework with a bunch of modules hacked together into an unreusable hierarchy, instead of small, simple modules that do one thing and one thing well? Sinatra literally isn’t supposed to be an all in one package. You should find the modules to do exactly what you need to do as they’re less “jack of all trades”. Think Unix.

That’s like saying why use Java, it comes with a ton of API and libs that you don’t even use. That doesn’t affect overall performance though does it.

So you get extra stuff with Rails, so what? It’s easy to customize that anyway.[/quote]It’s not about performance; it’s about maintainability, code cleanliness, good abstractions and separation of concerns. It’s easier for somebody to maintain a few simple packages that have a small scope than it is to maintain wheel reinventions. If every framework has to implement more features then that means that there are more potential bugs and that they are more likely to ‘half ass’ an implementation of something. It’s not about performance or convenience, it’s a matter of principle.

Read full topic

Sinatra literally isn’t supposed to be an all in one package. You should find the modules to do exactly what you need to do as they’re less “jack of all trades”. Think Unix.[/quote]
That’s like saying why use Java, it comes with a ton of API and libs that you don’t even use. That doesn’t affect overall performance though does it.

So you get extra stuff with Rails, so what? It’s easy to customize that anyway.

item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

I’ve been writing a web application using Django for the last few months for a software engineering class. I feel that I’ve been confined to restrictions based on the flexibility of Django itself, so unless you know how to rethink your ideas to fit Django’s framework, you might find difficulty with that. Also, in order to fully leverage Django’s power, you have to have a strong knowledge of web development (i.e. MVC, templates, database models, …) itself because of the power it contains. Though, there is a lot of ‘hand waving’ involved with some parts, so you don’t get as much control. Oh, and it also comes bundled with its own web server, so you don’t have to worry about that.

The last time I used Flask, I found it delightful and easy to follow, but I didn’t extensively look into its usage enough to grasp its full potential. There’s some fascinating things I’ve read about it though, so that’s a route to take.

Doing any sort of LAMP (Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP) work will give you full control of your web application. You’ll have to configure things from the ground up though. While it might be easy to get those four components running, the web application will need to be built yourself, unless you decide to use a framework (I have no experience using PHP frameworks).

I haven’t looked into RoR at all though, but the last time I tried it (a few years ago), it was a massive elephant of files to associate with a simple Hello World script, which turned me off.

So, to summarize, Django gives you a lot of power and less flexibility, LAMP gives you a lot of control and flexibility with deficiency in scaling, and Flask/RoR are uncertain to me. Seems like RoR is good though, from other replies I’ve read here.

Read full topic

item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Snow_, post:26, topic:547919”][quote author=stCky link=topic=666824.msg4459053#msg4459053 date=1416531958]
At my course, we were first taught HTML/CSS and basic Javascript. We then glanced over procedural PHP basics. After we understood the basics of syntax and functions we moved onto Object-Oriented PHP and MYSQL for database interaction. Then after those we were taught the basics of MVC and frameworks.

This is just a basic run-down of the path we took at my course, I was lucky enough to get a job before graduation and spent ~2 years banging out PHP jobs, e-commerce sites, blogs etc for small companys.

This year I started a new role as a node.js developer and can honestly say that node is the future. I toyed with RoR and from the get-go felt it was way too heavy. I found node to be a slight learning curve coming from PHP, with packages and server-side javascript and also having zero experience with command-line interfaces, but after a few months I’m more than competent and it’s really changed my perspective coming from PHP.

That isn’t so relevant now though, if you’re just starting to learn programming I’d suggest you look at object-oriented PHP and MYSQL for database interaction. The syntax is similar to JavaScript, when I was learning I felt it was familiar after learning js. You can take it a step further and start looking into MVC frameworks such as CodeIgniter or Laravel - these are a touchy subject though and web devs often argue about frameworks as much as we’ve seen people bitching over RoR in this thread.

Pick something that piques your interest and you can’t go wrong
[/quote]

Thanks for taking your time to write all of this!

I am however interested in Ruby.
Since some on this thread said Sinatra would be a good framework to start this project with, I went ahead and searched for some details on google.
Most of what I read pretty much confused me though.

I’m familiar with OOP (Java and C#.NET) and have some none to a little knowledge of Ruby by completing the codecademy courses.
Is there anything you guys can think of I should read up on first before actually starting? Like the HTTP protocol and such for example?[/quote]

Web frameworks are there, to some degree, to abstract the HTTP protocol away from the user and to provide tools that help manage some of the bulkwork you’d otherwise have to do when writing a web app. You still need to know a bit of stuff though.

If you don’t know Ruby, you can also just try another micro-framework similar to Sinatra but written in another language.

Read full topic

After we understood the basics of syntax and functions we moved onto Object-Oriented PHP and MYSQL for database interaction. Then after those we were taught the basics of MVC and frameworks.

This is just a basic run-down of the path we took at my course, I was lucky enough to get a job before graduation and spent ~2 years banging out PHP jobs, e-commerce sites, blogs etc for small companys.

This year I started a new role as a node.js developer and can honestly say that node is the future. I toyed with RoR and from the get-go felt it was way too heavy. I found node to be a slight learning curve coming from PHP, with packages and server-side javascript and also having zero experience with command-line interfaces, but after a few months I’m more than competent and it’s really changed my perspective coming from PHP.

That isn’t so relevant now though, if you’re just starting to learn programming I’d suggest you look at object-oriented PHP and MYSQL for database interaction. item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @stCky stCky
item.description:
@stCky wrote:

At my course, we were first taught HTML/CSS and basic Javascript. We then glanced over procedural PHP basics. After we understood the basics of syntax and functions we moved onto Object-Oriented PHP and MYSQL for database interaction. Then after those we were taught the basics of MVC and frameworks.

This is just a basic run-down of the path we took at my course, I was lucky enough to get a job before graduation and spent ~2 years banging out PHP jobs, e-commerce sites, blogs etc for small companys.

This year I started a new role as a node.js developer and can honestly say that node is the future. I toyed with RoR and from the get-go felt it was way too heavy. I found node to be a slight learning curve coming from PHP, with packages and server-side javascript and also having zero experience with command-line interfaces, but after a few months I’m more than competent and it’s really changed my perspective coming from PHP.

That isn’t so relevant now though, if you’re just starting to learn programming I’d suggest you look at object-oriented PHP and MYSQL for database interaction. The syntax is similar to JavaScript, when I was learning I felt it was familiar after learning js. You can take it a step further and start looking into MVC frameworks such as CodeIgniter or Laravel - these are a touchy subject though and web devs often argue about frameworks as much as we’ve seen people bitching over RoR in this thread.

Pick something that piques your interest and you can’t go wrong

item.title: Web dev technologies?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Snow_, post:21, topic:547919”]Thanks for the detailed answers!

Sorry if the following question seems retarded but keep in mind I have never done any web development yet!

Is it correct to say that everything discussed above is a backbone technology while HTML, CSS and JavaScript are used for the actual designing and making the site interactive?[/quote]
Yes. What we have been discussing is back end development, it all goes on behind the scenes for database manipulation etc whereas the HTML & CSS are the bare elements for the sites design. I didn’t mention JS because we did discuss Express/Node which are JavaScript backend frameworks, it can get a bit confusing for a beginner going into that.

Also bare in mind CSS3 is a great tool to bypass using something like jQuery when designing. CSS Animations & Transitions will be your best friend.

Read full topic
